cards.desc:
If you consider a customer that uses the portal of Sharepoint, what they want is using our platform for the custom app dev and workflows inside the Sharepoint portal their users already use and are used to. They want:

- SP to be the master of users and access control (even for processes)
- SP to be used for doc management
- SP to be used for collaboration
- SP to be used for content (e.g., emails, even the ones sent by the platform)
- SP to be used for reporting over OS data
- And most important they want it to be transparent to the user that he is using an OS app in some portions of the SP portal
- SP search capabilities
- maybe include SP's document-centric workflows integrated with BPT (e.g common inbox).
cards.name: Sharepoint demo & technote improvements

cards.desc:
- General Welcome letters for first installation are very confusing
- Error message in the platform after upgrading version is bad and should be tweaked to common use case (install new version without previously asking license upgrade - even though subscription allows it). Check UpgradeMessage.rtf
- Multi year agreements (now common) also receive confusing emails (license expiring -> purchase). Review mail process. Check MultiYearAgreements.rtf
- The license notification should also include the Platform Version the license refers to. It helps Acct Mgrs (and the Customer) to understand which version that license applies to (check PlatformVersion.pdf)
- The Edition should be cleaned to mention the exact details of the license (e.g. correct SUs or no SUs at all) - check mail from Eduardo Cruz (Your OutSystems Platform subscription is now active - see instructions inside. | extension for Main Energie, 24/06/2013)
cards.name: Licensing and Welcome letters process review for a better experience

cards.desc:
We have tons of requests for information on integrations with external authentication providers.
We should have a technote (or make it part of the security technote) that describes the most common ones and provides examples (e.g. OAuth, SAML, LDAP with groups synchronization, etc). 
It should be used as technical evaluation to reassure it is possible and easy.
cards.name: External Authentication scenarios technote

- Providing best practices

cards.name: Testing in the Agile Platform

cards.desc:
Create a small PDF that is sent in the registration process to "guide" users into what they should be checking and where.

This has proved to be very useful (and a low-tech-low effort) for VersionOne, specially because:
 - It is printable and a good fit for "long running" evaluations
 - It drives people to where we want them to spend their time evaluating
 - It shows how broad the product is (which is sometimes hard to perceive form the website)
 - It helps finding the appropriate resources

Check the attached example
cards.name: Evaluation checklist PDF

data.text:
High availability scenario - Montepio discussion around DB replication

5. Active front-ends on two distinct site. In this scenario, customer wishes to have the OutSystems Platform running with 2 active setups in two separate sites. Their problem is that communications between the user and the platform might be possible for Site2 but not for Site1, and they want to divert traffic to the other site.

We discussed 2 possibilities for this:
Assuming a very very very good network connection between the two sites (we are talking 100Mbps / 1Gbps) and using Oracle only, it can be done using Oracle RAC with two active-active nodes. Front-ends on both sites would use the local Oracle RAC node for both datamodel/metamodel and session model, and a load balancer would be used to balance front-ends on each site. Then at local office level it could be determined whether to access site1 or site2.

Still on the assumption of a very good network connection, but using SQL Server, it could be done with active-passive SQL Server mirroring: Front-ends on both sites would connect to primary SQL Server on Site1 and, in case of fail-over, fallback to SQL Server on Site2.

data.text: Held several meetings with Peter Christiansen. Results in Evernote: evernote:///view/2093268/s19/01c44349-6dd5-4a27-8e59-01938e2c5876/01c44349-6dd5-4a27-8e59-01938e2c5876/
Consider using the presentation, tools and methods prepared by  Andrew Burgess on the NextStep session. Put these in the forums

There are several approaches being discussed, a couple of components in the Forge to help (here, here and here), an internal component (used at GDF), etc.
There will also be a session at NextStep on this subject ("But what about testing?", Tech track)
The service for GDF is being tested by the Experts team for customers that have this demand.
I've added to our backlog to centralize this information so it can be reused. We'll pick it after NextStep together with the Experts team.
Meanwhile, if you have specific demand for this information, and think that what is being done at GDF may be applicable, please contact the Experts team.

data.text:
Mail from Ruud:

Guys,
 
Every now and then I ‘bumping’ into the question about our support for testing.
I would be great if APC or even better someone from product management could help us to formulate an official statement / advise for this topic.
 
I have searched forums for this topic and I found this one:
http://www.outsystems.com/forums/discussion/8197/automated-unit-and-integration-testing/
 
Would it be a possibility to start an OutSystems thread about this topic?
Or do we have a thread that I didn’t see?
 
Note: I know that we have a service that is used at GDF to run regression tests (using selenium). Is that something to offer as a standard offer? (see attached powerpoint about this service)
 
Can you please help me with this topic?

card.name: Welcome Letters review for a better install experience
